description: Borrowed from Old French frere, from Latin frater, from Proto-Indo-European *bʰréh₂tēr. Doublet of brother.

entries.meaning: any of one's male associates, friends, buddies, or companions
a friar; a male member of a mendicant religious order
examples: a. 1400,  Geoffrey Chaucer,  “The Summoner's Tale”, in  The Canterbury Tales, lines 1693-1696:Right so as bees out swarmen from an hyve, / Out of the develes ers ther gonne dryve / Twenty thousand freres on a route / And thurghout helle swarmed al aboute...Just like bees swarm from a hive / Out of the devil's arse there were driven / Twenty thousand friars on a rout / And throughout hell they swarmed all about...

entries.meaning: a friary; a religious institute for friars
(rare) a monk; a male member (a brother) of a monastic religious order
